attributes.Title: HnrsThesisSem-Rebels & Martyrs
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Japanese
499D
UMass Amherst
This capstone course addresses issues of rebellion and martyrdom in Premodern and Modern Japan under the rubric of "sacrifice." We will analyze primary and secondary literature as well as films on a variety of topics. For Premodern Japan, we will focus on human sacrifices in Noh drama, rebels following the Way of Tea, Japanese Christian martyrs, blood avengers, children as rebels and martyrs, peasant rebels, social rebels committing double suicide, and common folk calling the shots through religious world-renewal movements. For Modern Japan, we will explore the motivations of assassins in the late Tokugawa (Bakumatsu) and Meiji periods, of rebels in 20th-century feminist and proletarian movements, and of soldiers in the Pacific War. Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Chinse, BA-ComLit, BA-FrenSt, BA-German, BA-Ital, BA-Japan, BA-Port, and BA-Span majors. The prerequisite is Japanese 499C, The Samurai.
Open to Undergraduate Seniors & Juniors only. PreReq: Japanese 499C
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
18944
12282
Requisite: This capstone course addresses issues of rebellion and martyrdom in Premodern and Modern Japan under the rubric of "sacrifice." For Modern Japan, we will explore the motivations of assassins in the late Tokugawa (Bakumatsu) and Meiji periods, of rebels in 20th-century feminist and proletarian movements, and of soldiers in the Pacific War. attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Honors College
201

attributes.Title: ST-ExtensiveJapaneseReading1
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Japanese
297G
UMass Amherst
Students choose from a wide selection of Japanese books in the East Asian Collection and read at their own pace.  The important part of extensive reading is to choose a book where you understand 90% - 95% of the content.  In doing so, you can guess the meaning of a new vocabulary word based on the surrounding context without using a dictionary. Available texts cover a wide variety of genres and contain culturally relevant aspects of Japanese history and society to supplement materials studied in other courses.  Students read authentic texts while gradually improving their reading comprehension, creating book reports and a final presentation based on texts read.
JAPANESE 110 or 126  Prerequisite:  Japanese 110 or 126.  Students who are currently not enrolled in any Japanese language courses may enroll in the course.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Communicating in Japanese
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Japanese
494RI
UMass Amherst
This course is designed to help students become effective communicators in Japanese. The course uses the Team Based Learning format, meaning that students will do activities in teams. The first part of the course focuses on two key Japanese social concepts that have had extensive impact on communication: the uchi (inside)/soto (outside) distinction and the hierarchical order. In the second part of the course, we will look at two topics concerning Japanese culture?gender roles and the view of nature?and compare them to the American context in an attempt to deepen our understanding of both cultures. In the third and last part of the course, we will think of ways for us to support healthy relationships between Japan and the U.S. Use of English is allowed only in the first part.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Japan majors.  Prerequisite: Japanese 497A and Japanese 497B
Pre Req: JAPANESE 497A & 497B
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
62535
Requisite: This course is designed to help students become effective communicators in Japanese. The course uses the Team Based Learning format, meaning that students will do activities in teams. In the second part of the course, we will look at two topics concerning Japanese culture?gender roles and the view of nature?and compare them to the American context in an attempt to deepen our understanding of both cultures. attributes.Title: Lit-Classical & Medieval
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Japanese
143
UMass Amherst
Students will read in English translation the supreme masterpiece of Japanese literature, The Tale of Genji (ca. 1010), which is also the world's first novel and the only world classic written by a woman.  We'll also read The Tale of the Heike, a warrior epic inspired by the political intrigues and the horrors of the Genpei War (1180-1185). No prerequisites.  (Gen.Ed. AL, G)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: Japanese Art&Culture
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Japanese
135
UMass Amherst
Exploration of Japan's secular and religious arts and their impact on gendered literary texts, such as early aristocratic women's writings and medieval warrior epics. Films about the traditional theater, which influenced the culture of sexuality, and about the Zen-inspired art of the tea ceremony, which reflected political upheaval. Locating points of intersection between art and literature, religion and politics in modern Japan under Western influence. Conducted in English. No prerequisites.  (Gen.Ed. I, G)
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: College Writing
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
English Writing Program
112
UMass Amherst
ENGLWRIT 112 (College Writing) is a first-year college-level writing course designed to help students expand their ability to write essays for academic, civic, and personal purposes and to develop their rhetorical awareness to write effectively in new social contexts. Based on the assumption that writing is a social activity, this course requires active engagement in the writing process, including pre-writing, peer review, revision, and editing. Students write five essays. This is the only course at UMass Amherst which satisfies the General Education College Writing (CW) requirement. Prerequisite: Placement into ENGLWRIT 112 through the Writing Placement Exam or a passing grade in ENGLWRIT 111 Basic Writing. May not be taken Pass/Fail.  (Gen.Ed. CW)
Prerequisite: ENGLWRIT 111 (or adequate performance on Writing Program placement test). Pre Req: ENGLWRIT 111
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
61710

attributes.Title: Japan Lit-Modern
attributes.Description:
Fall
2015
Japanese
144
UMass Amherst
Introduction to Japanese literature from around 1600 to present. Alternating between reading poetry and prose and viewing classics of Japanese film. Discussion of the construction of love and death during centuries of national seclusion and in the era of Western influence. Focus on changing gender relations and on the status of discriminated against minorities. Conducted in English. No prerequisites.  (Gen.Ed. AL, G)
Multiple required components--lab and/or discussion section. To register, submit requests for all components simultaneously.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.

attributes.Title: ST-Communicating in Japanese
attributes.Description:
Spring
2015
Japanese
497R
UMass Amherst
This course is designed to help students become effective communicators in Japanese. The course uses the Team Based Learning format, meaning that students will do activities in teams. The first part of the course focuses on two key Japanese social concepts that have had extensive impact on communication: the uchi (inside)/soto (outside) distinction and the hierarchical order. In the second part of the course, we will look at two topics concerning Japanese culture?gender roles and the view of nature?and compare them to the American context in an attempt to deepen our understanding of both cultures. In the third and last part of the course, we will think of ways for us to support healthy relationships between Japan and the U.S. Use of English is allowed only in the first part.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Japan majors.  Prerequisite: Japanese 497A and Japanese 497B
Pre Req: JAPANESE 497A & 497B
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
19520
Requisite: This course is designed to help students become effective communicators in Japanese. The course uses the Team Based Learning format, meaning that students will do activities in teams. The first part of the course focuses on two key Japanese social concepts that have had extensive impact on communication: the uchi (inside)/soto (outside) distinction and the hierarchical order. In the second part of the course, we will look at two topics concerning Japanese culture?gender roles and the view of nature?and compare them to the American context in an attempt to deepen our understanding of both cultures. In the third and last part of the course, we will think of ways for us to support healthy relationships between Japan and the U.S. Use of English is allowed only in the first part.  Satisfies the Integrative Experience requirement for BA-Japan majors.  Prerequisite: Japanese 497A and Japanese 497B

attributes.Title: ST-ExtensiveJapaneseReading2
attributes.Description:
Spring
2016
Japanese
497G
UMass Amherst
Students choose from a wide selection of Japanese books in the East Asian Collection and read at their own pace.  The important part of extensive reading is to choose a book where you understand 90% - 95% of the content.  In doing so, you can guess the meaning of a new vocabulary word based on the surrounding context without using a dictionary. Available texts cover a wide variety of genres and contain culturally relevant aspects of Japanese history and society to supplement materials studied in other courses.  Students read authentic texts while gradually improving their reading comprehension, creating book reports and a final presentation based on texts read.
Pre Req: JAPANESE 327  Prerequisite:  Japanese 327.  Students who are not currently enrolled in any Japanese language courses may enroll in this course.
Permission is required for interchange registration during the add/drop period only.
